private_information: I can move one top block at a time and only manipulate blocks that are currently accessible to me.
I have direct control over the blocks that start in the stack containing C, I, F, D, and A.
robot1.goal: Execute assigned moves from the provided action sequence and report local observations and constraints.

private_information: I can move one top block at a time and only manipulate blocks that are currently accessible to me.
I have direct control over the blocks that start in the stack containing E, B, J, G, and H.
robot2.goal: Execute assigned moves from the provided action sequence and report local observations and constraints.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate reports from the two robots and produce a complete PDDL domain and problem targeting the FastDownwards solver that represents the blocks world instance and the final configuration after the given action sequence.

public_information: Standard BlocksWorld rules apply: only the top block of a stack may be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
There are ten blocks: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J.
Initial arrangement (bottom to top for each table stack): Stack1 = C, I, F, D, A; Stack2 = E, B, J, G, H.

The agents will execute the following ordered actions: 1 unstack(H,G); 2 stack(H,G); 3 unstack(H,G); 4 stack(H,A); 5 unstack(H,A); 6 stack(H,G); 7 unstack(H,G); 8 putdown(H); 9 pickup(H); 10 putdown(H); 11 unstack(A,D); 12 stack(A,G); 13 unstack(A,G); 14 stack(A,H); 15 unstack(A,H); 16 stack(A,G); 17 pickup(H); 18 stack(H,A); 19 unstack(H,A); 20 putdown(H); 21 unstack(A,G); 22 stack(A,H); 23 unstack(A,H); 24 putdown(A); 25 pickup(A); 26 stack(A,D); 27 unstack(G,J); 28 stack(G,A); 29 unstack(G,A); 30 stack(G,A).

Final arrangement derived from the initial arrangement and the action sequence is: A is on D, B is on E, C is on the table, D is on F, E is on the table, F is on I, G is on A, H is on the table, I is on C, J is on B.

observe.system_prompt: You are an agent in a BlocksWorld domain responsible for observing and manipulating blocks in one of the stacks. Provide a concise local observation of the initial stacks you can access and list any local constraints or assumptions you need for executing moves. Do not emit PDDL. Provide your report as a structured plain-text observation.
observe.prompt: Your name is robot1. You have the following public information: {environment->public_information}. You have the following private information: {agents->robot1->private_information}. Your goal is: {agents->robot1->goal}. Produce a concise single-message observation describing the stacks you see, which blocks are top and movable for you at the start, and any local assumptions or constraints you rely on to perform your assigned moves. Do not produce PDDL.

observe.system_prompt: You are an agent in a BlocksWorld domain responsible for observing and manipulating blocks in one of the stacks. Provide a concise local observation of the initial stacks you can access and list any local constraints or assumptions you need for executing moves. Do not emit PDDL. Provide your report as a structured plain-text observation.
observe.prompt: Your name is robot2. You have the following public information: {environment->public_information}. You have the following private information: {agents->robot2->private_information}. Your goal is: {agents->robot2->goal}. Produce a concise single-message observation describing the stacks you see, which blocks are top and movable for you at the start, and any local assumptions or constraints you rely on to perform your assigned moves. Do not produce PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent BlocksWorld modeling. Your task is to integrate the observations from the agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file compatible with the FastDownwards planner. The domain must model standard BlocksWorld actions (pickup, putdown, stack, unstack) with clear preconditions and effects and ensure single-handed agents and top-only moves. The problem must encode the initial state from the public information and the derived final arrangement as the goal. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Target FastDownwards compatibility.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You have to integrate the agents' observations to produce a PDDL domain and problem for FastDownwards that represent the instance described in the public information and whose goal is the final arrangement derived from the action sequence. Use the agents' reports: {obs_robot1} and {obs_robot2}. Use the public information: {environment->public_information}. Keep actions of multiple agents distinct only if necessary; otherwise produce a single-agent BlocksWorld domain appropriate for FastDownwards. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
